greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Peano curve in an n X n grid, starting rightwards from the top left corner, listed antidiagonally as A(0,0), A(0,1), A(1,0), A(0,2), A(1,1), A(2,0), ... .
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..13202

E. H. Moore, On Certain Crinkly Curves, Transactions of the American Mathematical Society, volume 1, number 1, 1900, pages 72-90. (And errata.) See section 7 (and in figure 3 rotate -90 degrees for the table here).
Giuseppe Peano, Sur une courbe, qui remplit toute une aire plane, Mathematische Annalen, volume 36, number 1, 1890, pages 157-160. Also EUDML (link to GDZ).
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Hilbert curve (this curve called "Hilbert II").
Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers
example: The top left 9 X 9 corner of the array shows how this surjective self-avoiding walk begins (connect the terms in numerical order, 0-1-2-3-...):
mathematica: Table[A[n - k, k], {n, 0, 12}, {k, n, 0, -1}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Mar 07 2021 *)
xref: Transpose: A163336. Inverse: A163335. One-based version: A163338. Row sums: A163342. Row 0: A163480. Column 0: A163481. Central diagonal: A163343.
See A163357 and A163359 for the Hilbert curve.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Jul 29 2009
